[h1]Castle Crashes[/h1]

-	Do you like building Castles?
-	Do you like hearing Stories?
-	Do you like optimized games?

No? Then this game is for you (sarcasm).

See, this game can have castles, just not in any combat oriented game mode. As for stories, you can make one up. Optimization, “What’s that?”

Hope you have a good imagination as you’ll need it to create any excuse for playing this game.

1) [u]The Story[/u]

What story? There is no story. Did you really expect a game titled “Castle [b]Story[/b]” to actually have a story? The so called “story” is that you, as the omniscient overlord of a bunch of Minion-colored Doctor Who Adipose creatures, called “bricktrons” must command these beings to defend their tiny floating island from the ~[i]eevviill[/i]~ (or perhaps misunderstood) rock monsters called “corruptrons”. These monsters have, as their name implies, corrupted one of the crystals on this floating island and now they want to claim the island for themselves. There are multiple islands to choose from but no story linking the defense of one island to another. You get to play in one of three game modes, Invasion, Conquest, or Sandbox.

2) [u]The Gameplay[/u]

The gameplay is similar to that of most RTS games where you order around various units to do tasks such as harvest resources, build structures, craft weapons, scout areas, and fight enemies. You begin with around five basic worker units (more or less depending on difficulty) and create assignments for them such as gathering materials to constructing your base defenses.

The first flaw of this game is that you can only ever have a maximum of fifteen (15) units, [spoiler]unless you manually change it.[/spoiler] That is the total of units altogether including combat units. The good thing is that you can change units between fighters and workers by simply having them equip or unequip their weapons (at a weapon rack). The bad thing is that for every unit lost, you lose not only a fighter but a worker as well.
 
The next flaw is that building anything takes time, real-time, and I don’t mean waiting for a progress bar to complete. I mean that if you want a castle to be built, they build it [b]brick by brick[/b], literally. They pick up one brick (admittedly the size of a character) and walk it from where it was found to where it gets placed. Castles are built using way more than a handful of bricks. But that’s not all. [b]Everything[/b] is done piece by piece.
 
Want a sword for your fighter? You need to mine enough rocks to build four bricks, then lay each brick to build a forge, then mine enough iron to make two ingots, place the iron in the forge, mine enough brimstone to melt the iron, cut down a tree to get logs, cut a log to get three planks, take each plank individually to make a workbench, then take each ingot to the bench to start making the sword. But wait, you can’t actually have the sword unless you have a weapon rack to place it on, so you need more planks to build that as well.

Didn’t like how long that took for one sword? Well, imagine that for [b]EVERYTHING[/b]. Now, you’d think more units means faster work but you only get up to 15 and only one can work on the bench while another works on the forge, and others work at gathering. Gathering and building tasks limit themselves to 8 workers each unless you create multiple work orders.

As for modes, Sandbox is the only mode in which you [b]even have a chance to build a castle[/b], as there are no enemies. Invasion mode is basically tower defense. You build some basic walls to slow the enemy down while your units, or more likely automated defenses, take them out before the enemy takes out your home crystal. Oh, and the enemies never need a castle. Conquest is the same except you can actually take out the enemy’s crystal as well.
 
Speaking of crystals, this is where your units spawn from, but only the home crystal. All of the crystals you capture only increase the spawn rate of your main crystal. Once you reach capacity, nothing else is gained from the crystals. If you lose a unit, a new unit will spawn in time or, if your unit’s “spirit” makes it back to the crystal, it will respawn on its own.

There is one more thing. The units have a fairly basic AI routine. They will occasionally auto assign themselves to any tasks you have created without you actually needing to tell them to. If a task needs to be completed, an idle unit will go do it, eventually. They will not fight unless they are already assigned as a fighter and likewise the same with doing work.

3) [u]Goofs and Glitches[/u]

More like Bugs and BS really. Where to begin on this one?

First, the more you do and the longer you play the more likely your game will start to experience stuttering. Frame rates will drop due to slowly increasing RAM usage and bad AI path finding and unit management. The more you “manipulate the land” the lower your frames will become because the game has to keep track of all the changes. This is likely due to the fact that all objects have physics and, when destroyed, will bounce around when they fall apart.

The game can support more units. There is a way to add more. The problem lies with how the units are handled by the AI. Unit path finding is marginal at best. Units will take the long way around if it is the first path calculated to reach the destination. Units gather items based on where they started when the task was assigned, not by where the nearest item is to the task. This becomes apparent when a unit crosses the entire map to pick up a brick when there is one just around the corner from them.

Multiple units assigned to the same task may become idle when they all target the same item and only one can pick it up. There have been many occasions where units simply stop what they are doing because “their destination no longer exists” (whatever they were targeting got occupied by another unit). This is most frequent when building larger objects.

There is also limited sound in the game. While sound effects play regularly, the actual music will play for a short time and then stop. There may be several minutes of silence between the short songs that play.
 
[u]Conclusion[/u]

I had this game on my wish list for years but never really felt the urge to get it. Just before I decided to remove it, someone got it for me. Now I know why I never got it.

I always felt like the building castles part was missing something, and now I know what it is, [b]THE CASTLES[/b]. Only when playing sandbox did I even get to build one and that took over six hours to build a small one. I created a level where it already had the bricks mined out so I could just build and not gather. The level almost wouldn’t load due to poor optimization.

As for other modes, this does not work as an RTS. When [b]EVERYTHING[/b] needs to be done in real-time, it becomes tedious and boring.

If you’re looking for anything more than a bad experience, save your money or get a different game.

Well I never thought the day would come but this game is finally out of Early Access.  I personally have been waiting for it for 4 years, others about 5.  The main gripe stemmed from the period of 2 - 3 years where pretty much nothing happened with the game and the dev's heavy handed tactics of dealing with the criticism.  Nonetheless all that is history now and I shouldn't be dwelling on that alone.

The game now is OK.  There is a variety of modes and maps, performance has greatly increased as has some of the AI and building options.  I would agree with some of the sentiment in the comments that the game is worth something like $10-$15 dollars if you are a fan of this sort of thing.

What the game does well:

Performance is decent.  Just about everything in the game is visible.  You don't just put resources and items into storage, the little characters will mine and craft things right before your eyes and place it into appropriate storage where you can see it.  Even when you craft the weapons kits every piece is always visible wherever it goes.  Say you want to craft an arbalast, the crossbow, hat and bolts will be carried one by one from the crafting table to the weapons rack where you can see it hanging there.  This might not mean much to some people but to me it's a great touch.

  It's the same when you are building your castles.  Each section can be destroyed individually and if some parts don't have enough support they will fall where they will lie until your bricktrons pick them up and rebuild or place them in stockpiles.  It makes it cool to watch the resources how they are collected and stored, transformed, and become parts of the construction.

  The mechanics of the game are pretty solid and in my experience unique.  The enemies are a little bland but they serve their purpose of creating danger and tension in the game modes that include them.

The tutorials and explanations are great and acceptable for those new to the game.

Also the community leader (Shato) I have to mention here.  He is a much better people person than the previous one.  I feel bad for Box because he copped a lot of flak but he also deserved it with what he was doing.  Whether he was doing that under orders from the devs or not I have no idea but for a while there was a really really bad environment for the game community.  So the guy that replaced Box is a big improvement, he seemed to have the will and patience to connect the devs with the public again and that is an understated accomplishment.

Things that are not so great:

  Well this is a difficult one as I am slightly biased but i will get into that briefly at the end.  The main issues I see with the game is a lack of content.  The concepts in the game are great, it could have possibly been a genre leader with a little more building options and a little more creativity when it comes the enemies and gameplay.  I really think a decent story (Castle Story???) and even a campaign could have been worked into this game.  Working with the awesome concepts this could have really shined.

  I would have been willing to bury the issues of the past completely and give this game a thumbs up.  But alas even though there is a decent variety of maps there isnt much to do after a while unless you want to mess around with some friends in the limited multiplayer.  Now this is just me, I am sure that there are plenty of people around that would be quite happy to play the game just to create different buildings so if that sounds like your thing then disregard my opinion on content.

So just to briefly sum up my reasoning for still not recommending this game, it is a personal taste and morality of early access issue on my part.  This is THE game for me that made me very wary of early access, the years I spent waiting for content and arguing for more transparency left me coming away from the game wondering why I was stupid enough to buy it.  Without the Early Access issues or with some decent utilization of the concept of the game I would have given it a 6 or a 7 out of 10.  But in the end I am going to have to give it a 5/10, it's not bad but its definitely not good.  For me if given the choice I wouldn't have bought it.  But for you if you like building stuff and a little bit of resource management then go out and buy it.  You won't regret it.

I try to avoid starting reviews with "I really wanted to like this game," but I was very much excited for this game back when it launched on Kickstarter. I bought it way back then, but never actually got around to playing it until recently. I've since put a fair amount of time into it, but unfortunately, getting enjoyment out of this game is like squeezing water from a stone. In a lot of ways, the game feels like an early backer build, not a finished product.

The first thing you'll start to notice, and grow even more frustrated with over time, is the awful AI of the Bricktrons (your units). AI isn't easy, but the Bricktron AI is exceptionally bad. You can give an instruction to place a single block, and watch three or four Bricktrons all carry a block to the location, one of them places the block, and the others have to carry their cargo all the way back. If you build a wall (a core gameplay mechanic), you'll likely see your Bricktrons building it up in jagged spikes rather than level by level, wasting plenty of time as Bricktrons climb up and down and up and down blocks to place them instead of just walking along a flat level. But the most astonishing failure of the AI is that they will explicitly ignore your commands. The gameplay of controlling your minions involves giving them an order to pick something up, watch them walk almost all the way to it, then suddenly turn around and run somewhere else. Why the AI is trying to find something to do [i]after you've given them an instruction[/i] is a question that boggles the imagination.

As for gameplay mechanics, I'm hard-pressed to deduce what the main game mode was intended to be. Sandbox is the first one the game wants you to play, but the vast majority of things you can craft and build relate to combat, so it doesn't serve much purpose except as a tutorial. Invasion is the next game mode on the menu, but it's completely unbalanced. And I don't say that lightly - the enemies spawn in waves faster than you can hope to revive any dead Bricktrons, and past the early waves there are so many enemies, and their health and damage increases to absurd levels. Melee equipment for your Bricktrons is functionally useless early on because they simply can't tank enough damage, and you are severely punished for letting your Bricktrons die. The last game mode is Conquest, which is the most robust by far - there are a series of crystals across the map both you and the enemy are trying to capture, and the enemy will regularly send units to attack you, so you need to be consistently improving your defences. It's definitely the most satisfying game mode, but that only serves to highlight the fundamental holes in the game's design.

The very premise of the game just doesn't work (and pardon me while I spend the rest of the review trying to explain). Others have pointed out the difficulty of building multi-story structures, which actually isn't terribly difficult to do - the game just doesn't tell you how to do that, because it's not designed around building structures. It's designed around building walls, to block off chokepoints and slow down enemies. Building an actual structure is pointless; the only purpose of building anything is to defend yourself from the enemy attacks. But then you run into the problems with combat: enemies can tear down your defenses incredibly quickly, and you have no good way of stopping them. All of the walls you see in screenshots don't work; your units generally can't shoot straight down, and enemies generally don't stand back to battle you at range. The enemies rush right up to your wall and tear it apart, and the bigger enemies (which spawn very regularly) can do so extremely quickly. You can try to set up a U-shaped barricade, with ranged units along the sides shooting across towards the walls, but the harder you try, the more frustrated you'll be with how little damage your units deal compared to how quickly the enemies can break things - and you'll also notice just how much damaged the big ranged enemy deals.

The result of all this is: rather than building a wall, you should actually want to build a moat. The enemies have absolutely no way of crossing a pit - if possible, all they can do is try to dig straight down, cross the pit, and dig their way upwards. Of course, then you just dig out the ground beneath your base, and leave it floating in the air. And you're suddenly completely secure from all of the enemies in the game. (If you want to get the achievement for reaching wave 60 (which requires you to actually [i]defeat[/i] wave 60, not just reach it), create a custom map with the enemy spawn on a tiny, separate platform in range of your ranged units). Of course, digging isn't easy, but not at all for the reason that would make sense. Your Bricktrons can actually dig quite quickly, but digging produces a [i]lot[/i] of extra resources (stone, iron, brimstone), and the Bricktrons won't mine any of it unless there's storage space for it. You won't be able to dig your moat, specifically because you won't have enough storage space for any of it. Of course, you could try to manually guide a Bricktron to dig it out, but you'll have to micromanage them block by block, and even if you decided it was worth the trouble, you'd never suggest that it was fun.

The point is, it's very telling that the core gameplay mechanic expected by the game is for you to build things, but the actual most effective strategy is just to destroy the world. I really do get the impression that the game's aesthetic (floating islands, voxel castles, Bricktrons) was the actual vision for the game, and the gameplay loop was added on as an afterthought. This game could have polished the combat mechanics a bit to make combat more functional - having higher-tier equipment (especially for melee) would go a long way in that regard - or the game could have gone in a different direction entirely, perhaps adding mechanics that actually related to the construction aspects (i.e. needing to build every Bricktron a room), and aspiring more towards a management game.

As it stands, Castle Story is little more than a novelty. Its mechanics are unrelated to each other and universally shallow; the game's main strength is just in its aesthetic (and don't get me wrong, it does look very good!). Tasks that feel like they should complete in five minutes always take hours - I didn't mention it, but completing the wave 60 achievement, without skipping ahead of waves, will take you 10 hours(!). Even at a low sale price, I would recommend you spare yourself the disappointment/frustration.

When an indie game gets five years in development, you expect the final product to exceed what was initially laid out in the kickstarter pitch that started it.  Yet, after putting in some time with the initial  full release of the Castle Story, it's clear that a good game does not always come from a good idea, even when it's given plenty of time and money for the process.

[h1]What happened here...[/h1]

Back when Kickstarter first started taking off, Castle Story hit the ground running like many of those early adopters of the platform and generated nearly seven times its funding goal.  Like many people, I got caught up in the fanfare of being on the ground floor of cool game ideas and backed this game along with plenty of others.  Some games I backed turned out well, but Castle Story seems to have had some real problems given that it was in development for so many years and delivered something that feels so clunky and lacks any real depth.  Looking at the KS trailer compared to the finished product, it's strange to see how little it has changed in all of that time and how the initial concepts of the interface seem to be even better than end result.  Whatever went down between August of 2012 and August of 2017 to give us the game that we got a few days ago must be an epic story that I'd love to hear.

[h1]So what's so bad about it?[/h1]

Like any game, the first things I do after tweaking settings and checking out the main menus is look for a tutorial.  Some games have it separate while others integrate it into the new game setup.  Castle Story just simply doesn't have one.  At least not anywhere in the game.  The tutorial that does exists is on youtube and it's not even linked in game.  This is something than can be forgiven in a lot of circumstances, especially if the game is intuitive or extremely simple, but Castle Story is neither of those.  The menu system, crafting, building, and virtually any aspect of the game features so little basic instruction that it's easy to spend your first ten minutes not progressing in any way.  I had the advantage of streaming these bits and having a helpful person guide me along in chat, but it was still overwhelmingly frustrating and straight away gave me a bad omen for what was to come.  When a game has such unappealing initial steps, it rarely redeems itself going forward.  Castle Story as not an exception.

The most egregious offense in this game is the gameplay UI.  It's hard to explain just how clunky it is, but it seems like when most developers try to limit the amount of clicks and submenus, Castle Story's developers seemingly do the opposite.  Actions will often have several paths to get to them, not even considering keyboard shortcuts.  Performing actions will have you going in to menus, doing long clicks and awkward combinations of right and left clicks, and resizing selection areas clicking arrows and dragging it around.  Even after many hours of using this, I still found myself making mistakes and not remembering what all I needed to do to get something crafted or built.  Yet, as I moved forward in the game, it was easy to see that cumbersome UI is a product of  poorly designed gameplay.

Nearly every aspect of the game involves a convoluted process to achieve.  It shares so much with other detailed 'city' building games like Settlers and Banished, it seems odd that more of those games' logical designs weren't implemented.  The real issue starts where most everything in the game starts the stockpile.  Rather than having a single building that workers will store resources in for retrieval, you're required to build a sea of these individual square stockpiles that eventually take up the vast majority of the space you're working in.  Each will hold an arbitrary amount of a single substance, however the problematic AI will often block in stockpiles so that empty ones can't be filled, and then if you're not micromanaging a task, they'll fill all of you stockpiles with a resource, preventing other resources from being stored.  If you want to use these resources to craft something, you may end up missing a component.  Yet rather than telling you this, or what things are missing in the UI, you have to click on the area something is being made and hover over it to find out what is missing, then fumble your way around trying to find out why it doesn't exists, or hasn't been harvested, or wasn't being stored, or wasn't being accessed from it's storage area.  Something that is normally handled in games like this with a simple menu system featuring clear concise information turns into a hassle that bogs the game down even more.

I had originally believed this game would feature a linear mission progression system that would have you going from map to map trying to succeed in taking it over and building an effective castle and community.  However, you're relegated to three choices, a conflict-free sandbox mode, an Invasion mode that has timed waves of enemies (called Corruptrons) that you must keep from destroying your home-base crystal, and Conquest where you also have random waves of enemies coming for your crystal, but your objective is to capture other crystals around the map.  These are all free form, so there's no real progression or anything.  A progressive mission design would help in allowing the player to at least learn how to play in lieu of a tutorial by slowly ramping up the requirements of each map.  

[h1]The heart of the issue[/h1]

When it all comes down to it, even if you stick with it long enough to get the hang of the game, playing Castle Story just feels like you're pulling a dozen anchors with glue on your knees and a stomach full of greasy fast food.  When you're not fighting the interface or the mechanics, you're trying to accomplish something that just takes too long.  I slogged through two and a half hours of a Conquest map trying to get the hang of the systems and inching forward.  By the time I searched the internet a couple dozen times and got my pitiful army wiped out a third time from the ever-spawning menace, I just didn't want to play anymore.  Building anything more than the bare minimum castle for protection was just a waste of time, and even doing that felt too slow.  Now, I think I should make it clear that I don't have problems with slow games.  I play games like this all the time and enjoy them.  The older I get, the more I find value and pleasure in games that are fun without making me test my reflexes at every turn.  Yet with Castle Story, no matter what I accomplish, it still feels like I'm trying to run through waist deep water in the process.

[h1]Any chance of recommendation?[/h1]

I wouldn't recommend Castle Story to probably 99% of the PC gamers out there.  There are many design flaws throughout and even if you manage to figure it out, it doesn't get much more appealing.  That 1% out there that would like it are people that really enjoy the aesthetic (which is nice) and want a game that takes some effort to learn.  But even then they're going to have to learn to appreciate the fairly shallow game that it actually is.  If you think you're the 1% here, give it a shot, but I can only say to do it when it's really really cheap.

I backed the Kickstarter years ago, and for a long time considered that to be a mistake.  The developers released the game way too early, in my opinion.  It was more of a tech demo for a long time.  Recent updates, however, have made it into an interesting actual game.

You have to mine multiple resources and build a castle.  There are multiple combat roles (knight, halberdier, archer, arbolist, alchemist/bomber, and wizardy healer thing), so there can actually be a bit of depth to unit placement and such.  There are also pylons that you need to use to heal your units, light the map at night, and capture additional "crystals" that are used to generate units, both friendly and not.  Like many other games, there are occasional enemies during the day, and lots at night.

There are multiple modes:
Creative - a peaceful building mode (you still have to mine resources and manage your Bricktrons, so it's not the same as the Minecraft mode)
Invasion - a wave-based horde-like mode
Conquest - spread across the map by capturing crystals.

There are still definitely places to improve.  Some of the pathfinding and AI for your Bricktrons can be a bit wonky or slow.  Multiple Bricktrons occasionally try to do the same thing, and after it's done, the other units just kind of stand there for a bit while they try to figure out what to do.  Sometimes the rules can be a bit unclear when it comes to what building blocks can be placed where (especially with the wooden platforms).  The developers seem to be quite active and communicate clearly, though, so I'm fairly optimistic.

I would recommend watching some recent gameplay to make sure you know what you're getting into, but it's definitely a game on the up-and-up.

I would only buy if you are interested in building cool looking castles in a sandbox environment.

Summary: Overall is a fun game, but does have its share of problems. It is more of a sandbox building game than a strategy game, as the strategy part is mediocre. Like lego it is kind of dependent on the player using their imagination to make the game fun rather than being inherently fun itself. 

Pros:
You build castles brick by brick, you can make very creative and cool looking castles.
The soundtrack is excellent.
Has a unique visual style, and excellent attention to little details (bricks "plop" when placed in a stockpile, each weapon is visible in a weapon rack etc).
Physics are really cool, and watching castles crumble is very fun.

Cons:
The building part of the game and the strategy part of the game do not mix well together. Taking extra time to build a cool looking castle simply isn't possible in conquest or invasion mode, especially because you can't build while paused! This means that there is very little reason to build anything other than a 2 brick high wall and a shooting platform.

For performance reasons, there is a 15 bricktron cap (the cap can be bypassed in sandbox mode with the debug menu).

Although the physics is cool, a collapsed tower can cause the game to start lagging pretty badly (even with the recommended system specs).

Sandbox tools are kind of limited. For example it would be nice to delete bricktrons or corruptrons, rebuild an exploded landscape, or cleanup a crumbled castle wall without having to wait for the bricktrons to do it.

AI pathfinding is bad, and bricktrons/workers can't do tasks efficiently.
Example: 2 bricktrons will try to build the same object, with both collecting the resources to do so, walking to the construction site, only for 1 of them to build it and the other to walk all the way back and drop off their unused resources.
For a strategy game, watching your AI workers waste time doing stupid things can be frustrating.

Conclusion:
Although games can be both a building and strategy game (like Rimworld), Castle Story's building does not fit with the strategy portion of the game. As a building sandbox game, it is quite fun (however is dependent on the player to use their imagination to have fun, kind of like lego). As a strategy game, it is mediocre because you are constantly battling the bad AI of your workers, and the main theme of the game (building castles) rarely ever applies, as a 2 brick high wall is about as effective as an elaborate castle with towers and fancy battlements.

I would only buy if you are interested in building cool looking castles in a sandbox environment.

TIPS TO ENJOY THIS GAME
===================
Castle Story is not perfect in its current 1.0 release, but there is a great game in there and perhaps these tips will give you a chance to enjoy the game within the two hour refund period ;)


1 ) There is in game help explaining all the basics, click on the '?' icon in upper right corner (and press 'P' to pause game while you read it).

2) Use the hotkey shortcuts (F1 - F5 keys), just using the 'F1' build key will save you several mouse clicks in the slightly fidely UI. Look in 'Options - Keybindings' for all the shortcuts and keys.

3) First thing you should do is chop down some trees, build one or two chopping blocks and a bunch of stockpiles (always have a few empty stockpiles so your cute yellow guys don't stop working).

4) If a task is not being worked on or completed, check you have the resources required and at least one empty stockpile if needed to store an 'item'. You can check what resources are required by holding RMB on the 'factory' (workbench, altar etc) and hovering mouse over the item to be (or is being unsuccesfully) crafted.

5) Following on from point 4 above, it is possible to set stockpiles to only recieve a specific item by holding RMB on the stockpile. Although over using this does more harm than good in my opinion, I do find it helpfull to do this for certain items on stockpiles placed close to the 'factory'. This helps you easily see if you have the required resources.

6) You can enable mouse edge scrolling in options, when playing fullscreen I had to enable 'allow mouse off sceeen' (or something) first.  Also, use ctrl-click to remove unwanted/misplaced block blueprints and there is a delete (trash bin) icon bottom right to remove selected task (it's easy to miss but super important sometimes).

7) And now the 'biggy' - the game starts to 'lag' (pauses/freezes), which can get quite bad - a few seconds freeze every 30 seconds later in a game!. In version 1.0 I have not been able to stop this completly, but it is possible to reduce it to infrequent short pauses. The issue is caused by the AI pathfinding on an ever changing 3D voxel landscape, so if you reduce the number of things pathfinding it helps. Use more soldiers and don't have too many builders/gatherers or leave some unspawned bricktrons in your home crystal and only spawn them (hold RMB on home crystal) to replace lost bricktrons (or set a bricktron to 'Do Nothing' - select him then HOLD RMB on him). Also, saving and then reloading the game every few hours can help.

So, would I buy this game (I was an early backer). I would probably not buy it at current price or until the 'lag' issue is resolved. However, I am still giving it a thumbs up as despite the issues, am loving playing it ;)

EDIT - If your bricktrons get stuck while mining, you can manualy tell said bricktron (or one of his yellow friends) to dig voxels by selcting bricktron then hold RMB on voxel to be dug and make a way out. If his bag gets full, select bricktron then hold RMB on him and select 'Drop Load'. I dont find this happens too often and the AI does a generaly good job of building stairs etc as they go, but occasionaly the rather simpleton bricktrons will be gazing up at the sky instead of concentrating on what there doing.

Note that the HOLD RMB radial menu options are dependant on the currently selected object (LMB click). So for example, if you have a soldier selected and hold RMB on a factory, you will get options to attack it etc - so you may need to LMB on the factory or empty terrain first if you want to manufacture something. Once you grasp this, the UI does start to make more sense ;)

EDIT: Update 0.9 still has the UI in a mess. I tried my best to jump back into it and I couldn't even figure out where the delete button was for tasks and I still can't work out how to undo placement. I'm going to say that my review below still stands at present.

---

I saw Castle Story on Kickstarter back in 2012 and wished I could have kick-started it, the concept was new and interesting, the graphics looked fresh and pretty and it looked like a fun game that would go somewhere. Well, 4 years down the line it still looks exactly like it did 4 years ago on that Kickstarter page.

As far as I see, there is no real 'gameplay' to it other than plan a castle, dig some quarry's or mines and then watch the little yellow dudes AI fail to get it them the build zone or even properly drop resources off.

Instead, you'll spend your game time watching your workers swap resources around with one another rather than building anything. It almost seems like they tried to implement a bucket brigade AI... which would work great if they gave the poor little workers a little more logic so they didn't run the exact same path when on the same task - because they then spend more time swapping resources between themselves and 'finding paths to blueprint' instead of running over there.

The problems around building make it really hard to even attempt the 'wave survival' game modes - because its takes so long to get a simple wall around it and the damage enemies do (even on easy) wipes out your meagre combat units really quickly (I survived 60 kills ~8 waves before losing but still didn’t even have a simple wall up because the yellow dudes couldn't decide or work out how to get places)

The final straw for me was putting 6 workers on a large build task. They'd keep stopping at the build site, even though there were plenty of resources and lots of room for movement. They just all kept saying they were going to the same pile of resources which I can only assume meant all 6 of their poor little AI's were clashing and blocking one another... without anyone actually moving!

Some bullet points of what bugged me the most (Version 0.5.1):

- The UI is terrible. Every action in-game relies on a right click and hold - it's not intuitive, it’s not clear and it’s not even explained to you. I had to go find a video tutorial on basic camera movement and building because it was so annoyingly unclear. Actions should speak for themselves and not have to be searched for.

- Speaking of UI, sorting what materials can be placed on a storage pad is ridiculous. If you want to make it specifically wood, it takes 5 right click, hold, and selects to set it so. You need a lot of storage, so multiply that by the number of space you want... it’s just plain silly.

- For a game about building castles its surprising tedious to build anything in (let alone a castle), you need more workers to get things done faster but the more workers you have the slower the build goes because they spend time bumping into one another and sometimes they just decide to have a stop work meeting.

- The game constantly lags and has miniature seizures for a few seconds every few seconds...

- As outlined, the AI is just shoddy. There are a few simple things that would make it miles more efficient... the best being a complete overhaul of their path-finding algorithm and how they interact with one another (not swapping resources every damn time they bump into each other!)

- The game could benefit from a 'speed up time' button... a lot.

Overall: 3/10

Just so much wasted potential.

Avoid at all costs - don't be fooled! There are better games out there!
